title: WSPD
text:
WSPD (1370 <a href="Hertz">kHz</a>) is a <a href="commercial%20radio">commercial</a> <a href="AM%20broadcasting">AM</a> <a href="radio%20station">radio station</a> <a href="city%20of%20license">licensed</a> to <a href="Toledo%2C%20Ohio">Toledo, Ohio</a>. It broadcasts a <a href="talk%20radio">talk radio</a> <a href="radio%20format">format</a> and is owned by <a href="iHeartMedia%2C%20Inc.">iHeartMedia, Inc.</a> The <a href="radio%20studio">radio studio</a>s and offices are located in downtown Toledo at Superior and Lafayette Streets.
By day, WSPD is powered at 5,000 <a href="watt">watt</a>s, using a <a href="omnidirectional%20antenna">non-directional antenna</a>. But to avoid interfering with other stations on <a href="1370%20AM">1370 AM</a>, at night it switches to a <a href="directional%20antenna">directional signal</a> with a three-<a href="tower%20array">tower array</a>. The <a href="transmitter">transmitter</a> is on Oregon Road near Wales Road in <a href="Perrysburg%20Township%2C%20Wood%20County%2C%20Ohio">Perrysburg Township</a>. The transmitter site still contains a small <a href="disc%20jockey">DJ</a> booth - reportedly the original broadcast studio. Programming is also heard on 144 watt <a href="FM%20translator">FM translator</a> W225AM at 92.9 <a href="Hertz">MHz</a> and on an <a href="HD%20Radio">HD Radio</a> <a href="digital%20subchannel">digital subchannel</a> of 101.5 <a href="WRVF">WRVF</a>.
Programming.
Talk and News.
Weekdays on WSPD begin with a news and information show hosted by Fred LeFebvre. Scott Sands hosts a local <a href="conservative%20talk">conservative talk</a> show in afternoon <a href="drive%20time">drive time</a>. The rest of the weekday schedule is <a href="radio%20syndication">nationally syndicated</a> programs, including "<a href="The%20Sean%20Hannity%20Show">The Sean Hannity Show</a>", "<a href="The%20Glenn%20Beck%20Program">The Glenn Beck Program</a>", "<a href="Joe%20Pags">The Joe Pags Show</a>", "<a href="Coast%20to%20Coast%20AM">Coast to Coast AM</a> with <a href="George%20Noory">George Noory</a>" and "<a href="This%20Morning%2C%20America%27s%20First%20News%20with%20Gordon%20Deal">This Morning, America's First News with Gordon Deal</a>".
Weekends feature shows on money, health, the outdoors, technology, law, guns and home improvement. Syndicated weekend programs include <a href="Kim%20Komando">Kim Komando</a>, "<a href="Bill%20Cunningham%20%28talk%20show%20host%29">Sunday Night Live with Bill Cunningham</a>", "<a href="Ric%20Edelman">The Truth About Money with Ric Edelman</a>", "<a href="Bill%20Handel">Bill Handel on the Law</a>", "<a href="Tom%20Gresham">Gun Talk with Tom Gresham</a>" and "<a href="Gary%20Sullivan%20%28radio%20host%29">At Home with Gary Sullivan</a>" WSPD features local newscasts on the top and bottom of the hour during morning drive. Other times of the day, world and national news from <a href="Fox%20News%20Radio">Fox News Radio</a> is heard at the start of each hour.
Sports.
WSPD has been the <a href="flagship%20%28broadcasting%29">flagship station</a> of <a href="University%20of%20Toledo">University of Toledo</a> <a href="Toledo%20Rockets%20football">Rockets football</a> and <a href="Toledo%20Rockets%20men%27s%20basketball">men's basketball</a> since the mid-1960s, heading a network of seven affiliate stations across Ohio, Michigan and Indiana, carrying all home and away games as well as the coach's shows for both sports.
The station is also the chief Northwest Ohio affiliate of <a href="Cleveland%20Indians%20Radio%20Network">Cleveland Indians Radio Network</a>. WSPD carries all weeknight and weekend Indians games that do not conflict with U-T broadcasts. Weekday afternoon games are heard on sister sports station <a href="WCWA">WCWA</a> <a href="1230%20AM">1230 AM</a>.
History.
WTAL.
Toledo's oldest radio station was first authorized by <a href="telegram">telegram</a> on August 24, 1923, with the station <a href="sign-on">signing on</a> the next day. The original owner was the Toledo Radio & Electric Company at 433 Superior St. The <a href="call%20sign">call sign</a> was sequentially issued: WTAL.
On July 11, 1927, George B. Storer formed the Fort Industry Oil Co., which initially sold petroleum products in Toledo and Cleveland. The company became an advertiser over WTAL. In 1928, Storer and brother-in-law J. Harold Ryan arranged to become investors in the station, The new owners renamed the station WSPD, after the "Speedene" brand of gasoline. The initial broadcast as WSPD was scheduled for 9:30 a.m. on February 21, 1928. One local publication said "we are informed that the management has also changed and some very elaborate programs are promised". The studios moved in 1928 to The <a href="Matthew%20C.%20Perry">Commodore Perry</a> Hotel where the station's master antenna system became a landmark along with the hotel's rooftop signage.
In 1931, Fort Industry Oil sold its petroleum business to concentrate on radio, and "Oil" was dropped from its corporate name. Fort Industry gained full control of WSPD in 1937. In 1952, it became the <a href="Storer%20Communications">Storer Broadcasting Co.</a>
New Antenna and Frequency.
In 1935, the WSPD radio transmitter site on Oregon Road went on the air. The antenna system on the roof of the Commodore Perry Hotel remained a part of the Toledo city skyline, even though it was no longer transmitting WSPD's signal.
On March 29, 1941, under the provisions of the <a href="North%20American%20Regional%20Broadcasting%20Agreement">North American Regional Broadcasting Agreement</a> (NARBA), WSPD moved to 1370 kHz. For decades, the station was commonly known as "Speedy 1370". Some locals still refer to the station as "Speedy" although that nickname is no longer officially used on the air. (Recently, traffic reports on WSPD were renamed "Speedy Traffic," a nod to the heritage slogan). For much of its history, WSPD was an <a href="network%20affiliate">affiliate</a> of the <a href="NBC%20Red%20Network">NBC Red Network</a>, carrying its dramas, comedies, news, sports, <a href="soap%20operas">soap operas</a>, <a href="game%20show">game show</a>s and <a href="big%20band">big band</a> broadcasts, during the "<a href="Golden%20Age%20of%20Radio">Golden Age of Radio</a>."
In October 1941, the original towers atop the 18-story <a href="http%3A//images2.toledolibrary.org/getdcdata_no_session.aspx%3Ftypesearch%3Dkeyword%26amp%3Bkey%3DCommodore%2BPerry%26amp%3BB1%3DSearch%26amp%3Bhow%3Dcp%23">Commodore Perry Hotel</a> were dismantled. The broadcast towers had become a familiar Downtown Toledo landmark but had not been operated since 1935 when the stations present transmitter location went on the air.
FM and TV Stations.
In 1946, WSPD added a <a href="sister%20station">sister station</a>, WSPD-FM 101.5 MHz (now <a href="WRVF">WRVF</a>). And in 1948, WSPD-TV went on the air. The TV station's call letters changed to <a href="WTVG">WTVG</a> in 1979 when the radio stations were sold off to Wood Broadcasting, and Storer Broadcasting retained control of the TV station. An FCC regulation at the time dictated that TV and radio stations in the same market, but with different ownership, had to have differing call signs.
WSPD was the <a href="flagship%20%28broadcasting%29">flagship station</a> of Storer Broadcasting until late 1979, when it was spun off to "WSPD, Inc." Toledo Broadcasting Inc. acquired the station in 1986; eventually it would be sold to <a href="Jacor%20Communications">Jacor</a>, which sold the station in 1999 to <a href="iHeartMedia%2C%20Inc.">iHeartMedia, Inc.</a> (formerly Clear Channel Communications). In the early 1990s as well as across the country radio consolidation affected the small independent stations, WSPD transitioned from a full-service <a href="adult%20contemporary">adult contemporary</a>/<a href="Middle%20of%20the%20road%20%28music%29">MOR</a> station to its current corporate news/talk format - mainly with an slight partisan <a href="Conservatism">conservative</a> focus - and became known as "News Radio 1370 WSPD." The station went by the slogan "News/Talk 1370" from late 2005 until the winter of 2011. The station has since reverted to the "News Radio 1370 WSPD" slogan.
Past Personalities.
Although only 5,000 watts, WSPD had enormous influence in the Toledo <a href="media%20market">media market</a> due to the station's once high ratings. Some on-air alumni of WSPD include: <a href="Connie%20Desmond">Connie Desmond</a>, Art Barrie, Jim Ubelhart, Jeanne Overton, Bob Seybold, Randy Huston, <a href="Jean%20Shepherd">Jean Shepherd</a>, Bob Martz, Don Edwards, Neal Carmean, Chuck Parmelee, Ed Hunter, Jerry Keil, Eddie Kootz, Frank Venner, Ron Tindall, Bill Nordstrom, Ted Dalaku, Jim Donkel, Kent Slocum, Jack Mitchell, Mary Beth Zolik (Mitch & Mary Beth in the morning) Ed Burns (who had the station's first overnight country show), Gene Packard, Lee Conklin, Jim Harpen, Bill Stewart, Jude LaCava, Joe Gunderman, Dave Macy, Lee Kirk, Mike Shepherd, Pat Brogan, Deborah Boyce, Roy E. Blair - News Announcer & Broadcast Standards Manager, Rich Hoffer, Jerry Anderson, Larry Weseman, Art Edgerton, Lou Hebert, Buddy Carr, Mike Stanley, Paul Stowers, <a href="Paul%20W.%20Smith">Paul W. Smith</a>, Jim (Ted) Bayer, Doug Bermick, Maggie Moore, Paula Pennypacker, <a href="Sean%20Baligian">Sean Baligian</a>, Scott Sloan, City Councilman Dennis Lange, Mark Standriff, Dick Scott, <a href="Bob%20Frantz">Bob Frantz</a>, <a href="Denny%20Schaffer">Denny Schaffer</a> and Brian Wilson.
WSPD was also instrumental in the early singing career of Toledo-native <a href="Teresa%20Brewer">Teresa Brewer</a>, who performed on the radio station as a child in the 1930s. Deborah Boyce hosted the first nightly <a href="jazz">jazz</a> show in the country on AM radio from 1977-1979.
HD Radio and Translator.
On September 14, 2007, WSPD began 24-hour <a href="HD%20radio">HD radio</a> broadcasting. WSPD formerly broadcast in <a href="AM%20Stereo">AM Stereo</a> in the 1980s and 90s. By 2018, WSPD had discontinued HD <a href="IBOC">IBOC</a> broadcasting. But as of 2020, a stereo audio feed of WSPD is broadcast over sister station 101.5 <a href="WRVF">WRVF</a>-HD2.
On October 21, 2015, WSPD added an <a href="FM%20translator">FM translator</a> at 92.1 MHz, W221BG. While the transmitter was in the testing and measurement phase, it was on and off-air. The former location of the translator was in <a href="Rudolph%2C%20Ohio">Rudolph, Ohio</a>. The translator is owned by <a href="Educational%20Media%20Foundation">Educational Media Foundation</a> (EMF), parent company of the <a href="Christian%20radio">Christian radio</a> networks "<a href="Air%201">Air 1</a>" and "<a href="K-Love">K-Love</a>." iHeart media leased the translator from EMF. That translator is now W220EM at 91.9 MHz, <a href="simulcast">simulcast</a>ing EMF's <a href="WPAY%20%28AM%29">WPAY</a>, and iHeart has since moved WSPD programming to a new translator, 92.9 W225AM.
